channel.title: Vps
channel.description:
Ive got questions about vps's. I plan on buying one to host my server and Ive searched all over google for tutorials on how to set up things and they all seem complicated because I do not understand a single thing theyre talking about. Is setting up vps's that difficult?
My questions: If i shut off my computer, will my server be online? How does a vps work? Where can i find a cheap and easy setup vps hoster?

item.title: Vps
item.dc:creator: @ultimatepkvillage ultimatepkvillage
item.description:
@ultimatepkvillage wrote:

no it will not be online unless you have another computer your hosting from and one for vps but its basically like your hosting the server with vps on one computer anyways

Read full topic

item.title: Vps
item.dc:creator: @Karma_k Karma k
item.description:
@Karma_k wrote:

so even if i have a vps. and shut off my computer. my server would still be online? dam. lol

Read full topic

item.title: Vps
item.dc:creator: @itai itai
item.description:
@itai wrote:

[quote=“Team_Rocket, post:7, topic:427344”][quote author=zach55200 link=topic=530040.msg3869432#msg3869432 date=1325235599]
I’ve never experienced a problem with vpsland, I would recommend them. You just buy the vps, wait 1-48 hours and they will messege you with your vps details (IP, password)

How to use the VPS.

-Open up remote desktop connection

-Click “options”, “local resources” click “more” then check “drives”

-Click start, then computer open you d:/ and copy/paste your source or what ever file you want.

-After that log into the vps with your remote desktop connection using your login credentials that vpsland gives you after you purchase it.

-When on your VPS, click start then computer then open the d:/ and your files should be in there

https://portal.vpsland.com/?affid=407
any other questions feel free to ask.
[/quote]

I recommend against using VPSLand, I’ve had bad experiences with them years ago. They might be better now though. If you lurk enough on Google, you can find sites offering VPS trials for 1 month+.[/quote]
I agree, vpsland is very bad and overpriced. I suggest wooservers (if you don’t mind linux).

Read full topic

item.title: Vps
item.dc:creator: @Team_Rocket Team_Rocket
item.description:
@Team_Rocket wrote:

[quote=“zach55200, post:4, topic:427344”]I’ve never experienced a problem with vpsland, I would recommend them. You just buy the vps, wait 1-48 hours and they will messege you with your vps details (IP, password)

How to use the VPS.

-Open up remote desktop connection

-Click “options”, “local resources” click “more” then check “drives”

-Click start, then computer open you d:/ and copy/paste your source or what ever file you want.

-After that log into the vps with your remote desktop connection using your login credentials that vpsland gives you after you purchase it.

-When on your VPS, click start then computer then open the d:/ and your files should be in there

https://portal.vpsland.com/?affid=407
any other questions feel free to ask.[/quote]

I recommend against using VPSLand, I’ve had bad experiences with them years ago. They might be better now though. If you lurk enough on Google, you can find sites offering VPS trials for 1 month+.

Read full topic

item.title: Vps
item.dc:creator: @ultimatepkvillage ultimatepkvillage
item.description:
@ultimatepkvillage wrote:

My questions: If i shut off my computer, will my server be online? How does a vps work? Where can i find a cheap and easy setup vps hoster?
  1. If you shut off your computer the server will be offline. Its better just to host on the computer with the vps and setup the server on there so you won’t need to turn it off
  2. The software/program brings more ram, gig and etc to your computer to allow more free space.
  3. Not sure, and I heard cheap vps are not that good for hosting

Read full topic

item.title: Vps
item.dc:creator: @zach55200 zach55200
item.description:
@zach55200 wrote:

I’ve never experienced a problem with vpsland, I would recommend them. You just buy the vps, wait 1-48 hours and they will messege you with your vps details (IP, password)

How to use the VPS.

-Open up remote desktop connection

-Click “options”, “local resources” click “more” then check “drives”

-Click start, then computer open you d:/ and copy/paste your source or what ever file you want.

-After that log into the vps with your remote desktop connection using your login credentials that vpsland gives you after you purchase it.

-When on your VPS, click start then computer then open the d:/ and your files should be in there

https://portal.vpsland.com/?affid=407
any other questions feel free to ask.

Read full topic
